item.title: Goldman Sachs General Counsel Kathryn Ruemmler Resigns Over Epstein Ties
item.description: Kathryn Ruemmler, a former top Obama administration lawyer, is out at Goldman Sachs after emails showed a friendship with the sex offender Jeffrey Epstein spanning many years.
item.dc:creator: Rob Copeland, Maureen Farrell, Lauren Hirsch and Duy Nguyen
item.media:credit: William B. Plowman/NBC
item.media:description: Kathryn Ruemmler, the general counsel at Goldman Sachs, in 2014. She said Thursday that her responsibility “is to put Goldman Sachs’s interests first.”

item.title: El Paso Incident Highlights Gaps in America’s Drone Defense Industry
item.description: The U.S. has spent billions of dollars developing counter-drone technology, but much of it needs more testing in the real world.
item.dc:creator: Farah Stockman
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Center for a New American Security
item.media:credit: Jose Luis Gonzalez/Reuters
item.media:description: Many flights at El Paso International Airport were canceled on Wednesday, when the Federal Aviation Administration shut down air traffic there for hours.

item.title: Trump’s Actions Test the Fragile World of Air Travel
item.description: Last-minute announcements and abrupt changes by the Trump administration have caused confusion in an already strained U.S. aviation system.
item.dc:creator: Niraj Chokshi and Christine Chung
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Paul Ratje for The New York Times
item.media:description: A nearly deserted security checkpoint at El Paso International Airport on Wednesday after the Federal Aviation Administration announced a 10-day ban on flights over the city.

item.title: Flexibility and Rising Costs Are Keeping Mothers at Work
item.description: Labor force participation for women with small children continues to float above prepandemic levels, thanks to flexible work setups — and rising costs.
item.dc:creator: Sydney Ember
item.media:credit: Rebecca Kiger for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kelsey Whitlatch, 28, of Moundsville, W.Va., said she considered not working to focus on her children, ages 5 and 2. But with the rising costs of groceries and utilities, her family needs the second income.

item.title: Americans Are Paying the Bill for Tariffs, Despite Trump’s Claims
item.description: Research from the New York Fed confirms that U.S. companies and consumers are bearing tariff costs, despite the president’s assertions otherwise.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson and Sydney Ember
item.category: Bank of New York Mellon Corporation
Federal Reserve Bank of New York
item.media:credit: Mark Abramson for The New York Times
item.media:description: U.S. companies and consumers are paying most of the cost of tariffs, in the form of higher prices.

item.title: Europe Worries Trump Poses Threat to Its Financial and Tech Sovereignty
item.description: European leaders have been compelled to address the possibility of once-remote risks to the financial networks and technology that undergird their economies.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen and Adam Satariano
item.media:credit: Nicolas Tucat/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The European Commission’s headquarters in Brussels. The Trump administration’s embrace of cryptocurrency has ratcheted up European concerns about control of the euro.

item.title: Dutch Prosecutors Fine Louis Vuitton Netherlands in Money Laundering Case
item.description: The Dutch subsidiary of the luxury brand agreed to pay a nearly $600,000 settlement in a money laundering and terrorism financing case.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses

item.title: South Korean Court Rules Against Women in LG Inheritance Lawsuit
item.description: The widow and two daughters of LG’s former chairman sought to invalidate an inheritance agreement, claiming they were deceived into forfeiting their rightful inheritance.
item.dc:creator: Daisuke Wakabayashi and Grace Moon
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: From left: Koo Yeon-kyung; Kim Young-shik; and Koo Yeon-sue at their home in Itaewon, Seoul, in 2023.

item.title: The Giant Super PACs Fighting Over A.I. Safety
item.description: Anthropic is pouring millions of dollars into a political action committee that will most likely face off against OpenAI.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Niko Gallogly, Brian O’Keefe and Ian Mount
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dario Amodei, the C.E.O. of Anthropic, has supported tighter regulation around artificial intelligence.

item.title: States Say No Thanks to Trump Tax Cuts, Drawing Republican Fire
item.description: State income taxes often reflect federal policies, but Washington, D.C. and some states have taken steps to keep the latest Republican changes out of their tax codes.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Duehren
item.media:credit: Eric Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Mayor Muriel Bowser of Washington and other local officials warned that a sudden change to the city’s tax code would upend filing season in the capital.

item.title: Ford Will Make a Play for a Different Battery Market
item.description: The company, long focused on cars and trucks, plans to begin manufacturing large batteries used by utilities, data centers, other businesses and homeowners.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ewing
item.media:credit: Jon Cherry for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ford’s closed battery plant in Glendale, Ky., which it plans to revamp to produce large storage batteries.

item.title: New Method Can Find Hidden Eggs to Aid in Fertility Treatment
item.description: A study reported that the conventional method of searching follicular fluid didn’t find all the eggs. The new technology found extra eggs more than half the time.
item.dc:creator: Pam Belluck
item.media:credit: Cassandra Klos for The New York Times
item.media:description: A viable egg found by the OvaReady device that was not found using the conventional method.

item.title: Laid-Off Battery Plant Workers Pin Blame on Ford, not Trump, for Lost Jobs
item.description: Ford Motor shut down a battery factory and laid off 1,600 workers after President Trump and Republicans gutted government support for electric vehicles.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ewing
item.media:credit: Jon Cherry for The New York Times

item.title: To Stay in Her Home, She Let In an A.I. Robot
item.description: At 85, Jan Worrell lived alone on a remote corner of the Washington coast. Could ElliQ become her companion?
item.dc:creator: Eli Saslow
item.media:credit: Ruth Fremson/The New York Times

item.title: Bans on Many CBD Products Loom This Year
item.description: A federal law taking effect in November severely limits the amount of THC, the euphoric cannabis compound, allowed in over-the-counter items. Many groups are fighting back.
item.dc:creator: Jan Hoffman
item.media:credit: Bryan Anselm for The New York Times

item.title: It’s a Grocery Store, but Selling Food Isn’t the Point
item.description: Happier Grocery in New York is an entry point for people seeking a community built on inside knowledge. It’s not the only high-end grocer doing this.
item.dc:creator: Dalya Benor
item.media:credit: Amy Lombard for The New York Times
item.media:description: At Happier Grocery, the food sales are, perhaps, beside the point.

item.title: Maybe America Needs Some New Cities
item.description: It sounds a bit kooky to promise a whole city from scratch. But it has been done before — and might just help solve the housing crisis.
item.dc:creator: Conor Dougherty

item.title: Olympic Figure Skaters Are on Thin Ice Over Music Copyright Rules
item.description: Some Olympic athletes have found themselves caught up in controversies over musical choices before and during one of the biggest competitions of their careers.
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja
item.media:credit: Vincent Alban/The New York Times
item.media:description: The Canadian ice dancing pair Zachary Lagha and Marjorie Lajoie performing on Saturday in Milan.

item.title: India’s Prime Minister Faces Blowback Over Trade Deal With Trump to Lower Tariffs
item.description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi won a big reduction of sky-high tariffs, but critics say he undermined Indian sovereignty and undercut the nation’s farmers.
item.dc:creator: Alex Travelli
item.media:credit: Altaf Hussain/Reuters
item.media:description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India secured a new trade deal with the United States that had few details.

item.title: Sales at McDonald’s Rise, Driven by Value Meals and Grinch Socks
item.description: Profits were up as the fast-food giant focused on price-conscious customers. But the company said it would cut back on financial support for franchisees.
item.dc:creator: Julie Creswell
item.media:credit: John Taggart for The New York Times
item.media:description: It has been a tough slog for restaurants over the past year as many contend with a slowdown in eating out among consumers.

item.title: U.S. Health Officials Defend Rejection of Moderna’s Flu Vaccine
item.description: The F.D.A.’s refusal to examine the company’s mRNA shot drew widespread criticism from doctors and was divisive within the agency.
item.dc:creator: Christina Jewett
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Marty Makary, the F.D.A. commissioner, suggested that the agency might eventually approve Moderna’s mRNA flu vaccine.

item.title: Five Surprising Moments With Anna Wintour and Chloe Malle, U.S. Vogue’s New Top Editor
item.description: What is Ms. Wintour’s alternative career path? Who does Ms. Malle hope to rub elbows with at the Met Gala? More from our interview with American Vogue’s past and present.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Testa, Chevaz Clarke and Daniel Fetherston
item.media:credit: The New York Times
item.media:description: Anna Wintour and Chloe Malle in their first joint interview since Ms. Malle became editor of American Vogue in September.

item.title: New Kraft Heinz CEO Says Food Company Won’t Split, for Now
item.description: The company’s new C.E.O. said he saw opportunities to fix and grow the food giant — and cut prices for consumers.
item.dc:creator: Julie Creswell
item.media:credit: Daniel Cole/Reuters
item.media:description: Kraft Heinz said Wednesday that it was reversing plans to divide the company in two.

item.title: What to know about the better-than-expected report.
item.dc:creator: Lydia DePillis

item.title: Federal Debt to Hit Record Levels, Budget Office Warns
item.description: President Trump has reshaped the country’s economic policies, but the outlook for the budget remains dire.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Duehren
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: The federal debt is expected to grow under President Trump, the Congressional Budget Office said in its latest forecast.

item.title: Wall St. and Washington Brace for a Big Jobs Report
item.description: A hiring slowdown and fears about artificial intelligence have investors on edge, and some in the Trump administration on the defensive.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Niko Gallogly, Brian O’Keefe and Lauren Hirsch
item.media:credit: Lexi Parra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Today’s jobs report is expected to show that the recent slowdown in hiring was no mirage.

item.title: Trump plans to nominate a ‘data nerd’ to lead Bureau of Labor Statistics.
item.dc:creator: Ben Casselman

item.title: What Executives Are Saying About the ‘K-Shaped’ Economy
item.description: Leaders across industries from airlines to packaged foods have said a growing divide between lower-income and wealthy consumers is changing their businesses.
item.dc:creator: Kailyn Rhone
item.media:credit: Ruth Fremson/The New York Times
item.media:description: Consumers are “worried about overall affordability,” one executive said.

item.title: Kalshi and Polymarket Create New Competition for Professional Economists
item.description: Economists have noticed that betting markets like Kalshi and Polymarket are pretty good at predicting not just political events but economic data, too.
item.dc:creator: Lydia DePillis
item.media:credit: Andrea Chronopoulos

item.title: Lower Unemployment Rate Supports Longer Pause for Fed
item.description: January’s jobs data, released on Wednesday, bolstered expectations that the Federal Reserve will hold interest rates steady for longer than previously expected.
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith
item.media:credit: Caroline Gutman for The New York Times
item.media:description: The unemployment rate has become a focal point for the Federal Reserve, led by Jerome H. Powell, as it assesses the health of the labor market.

item.title: Job Growth Was Overstated, New Data Shows
item.description: Annual revisions show that employers added far fewer jobs in 2024 and 2025 than previously estimated.
item.dc:creator: Ben Casselman
item.media:credit: Daniel Becerril/Reuters
item.media:description: So-called benchmark revisions by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, an arm of the Department of Labor, have typically been small and attracted relatively little attention. But last year’s adjustment was the largest in years.

item.title: After a Year of Sluggish Hiring, 2026 Is Off to a Stronger Start
item.description: The economy added substantially more jobs than expected last month, as more people entered the labor force and wages grew.
item.dc:creator: Lydia DePillis

item.title: How the Ultra-Rich Travel
item.description: Inside the arms race to satisfy travelers for whom exclusivity is everything and money is no object.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Lyall

item.title: How Did Pat McGrath Cosmetics Go From Billion-Dollar Brand to Bankruptcy?
item.description: The makeup artist Pat McGrath was a favorite of Taylor Swift, Kim Kardashian and Madonna. Then she became a billion-dollar brand.
item.dc:creator: Linda Wells
item.media:credit: Yvonne Tnt/BFA.com, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Pat McGrath in 2024.

item.title: Trump Decries a ‘Nation of Renters’ but His New Policy Promotes One
item.description: President Trump’s recently announced executive order that would bar big investors from acquiring single-family homes includes an exemption that allows them to build homes for rent.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Goldstein
item.media:credit: Will Crooks for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Tricon rental home community in Simpsonville, S.C. Newly built rental housing is permitted under President Trump’s executive order.

item.title: Trump Wants to Revive Shipping. Investors Are Slow to Back Him.
item.description: A French logistics behemoth promised $20 billion for the United States, but a year into President Trump’s second term, only a fraction of the money has arrived.
item.dc:creator: Peter Eavis
item.media:credit: Maansi Srivastava for The New York Times
item.media:description: “He’s going to be investing $20 billion into the United States because of the election,” President Trump said last year when Rodolphe Saadé, the chief executive of the shipping company CMA CGM, visited the White House.

item.title: F.D.A. Refuses to Review Moderna Flu Vaccine
item.description: The vaccine maker’s shots involve the successful Covid vaccines’ RNA technology. Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. has broadly rejected it, canceling millions of dollars in research projects.
item.dc:creator: Christina Jewett and Rebecca Robbins
item.media:credit: Brian Snyder/Reuters
item.media:description: Moderna is a pioneer in using mRNA technology, first with the Covid vaccine. Its flu shot was being developed for people 50 and older.

item.title: Ford Says Electric Vehicle Losses Will Continue for 3 More Years
item.description: Ford Motor reported a big loss for 2025 because of its troubled electric vehicle division, which it has significantly scaled back.
item.dc:creator: Neal E. Boudette
item.media:credit: Brett Carlsen for The New York Times
item.media:description: An F-150 Lightning electric pickup truck, which the company stopped producing last year, after federal tax credits for electric vehicles ended.

item.title: Epstein Files Reveal Efforts to Build Ties With Russian Officials, Including Putin
item.description: New documents detail Jeffrey Epstein’s efforts to foster strategic, sometimes reciprocal relationships with Russian officials.
item.dc:creator: Steven Lee Myers and Nataliya Vasilyeva
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: The latest released files show that Jeffrey Epstein had hoped to facilitate a meeting with the Russian president, Vladimir V. Putin.

item.title: NLRB Dismisses Case Brought by Fired SpaceX Employees
item.description: The National Labor Relations Board, having accused the company of unfair retaliation in 2024, now says it has no jurisdiction over Elon Musk’s space company.
item.dc:creator: Noam Scheiber and Ryan Mac
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
item.media:description: Eight SpaceX employees were fired soon after asking the company to distance itself from comments made by Elon Musk, including one in which he made light of accusations of harassment directed at him.

item.title: The Whiskey World Is Reeling, but Uncle Nearest Has Bigger Troubles
item.description: A new report paints a grim financial picture of Uncle Nearest, a high-profile brand named for an enslaved distiller. But its founder disputes the findings.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.media:credit: Laura Partain for The New York Times

item.title: Ahead of Jobs Report, White House Seeks to Downplay Any Slowdown
item.description: President Trump’s top aides have argued in recent days that the economy is strong, even if new data on Wednesday show sluggish hiring.
item.dc:creator: Tony Romm
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: For the president, a dour jobs report could prove politically noxious.

item.title: Epstein Directed Aide to Obtain Hidden Video Cameras
item.description: “I’m installing them into Kleenex boxes now,” the aide replied in the 2014 email exchange.
item.dc:creator: David Enrich and Debra Kamin

item.title: Lutnick, Wasserman and Others Caught Up in Epstein Files
item.description: Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick and Casey Wasserman, the entertainment mogul, are among those facing blowback amid the release of files related to Jeffrey Epstein.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Niko Gallogly and Brian O’Keefe
item.media:credit: Heather Diehl/Getty Images
item.media:description: Representatives Ro Khanna, Democrat of California, and Thomas Massie, Republican of Kentucky, are part of a bipartisan political push to shed more light on the Jeffrey Epstein ordeal.

item.title: BP Suspends Share Buybacks as Profit Slumps
item.description: The British energy giant said it would put money toward new oil and gas opportunities ahead of the arrival of its new chief executive, Meg O’Neill.
item.dc:creator: Stanley Reed
item.media:credit: Luke Macgregor/Reuters
item.media:description: BP is turning back to its traditional oil and gas business in an effort to revive its fortunes.

item.title: Operator of Eddie Bauer Stores Files for Bankruptcy
item.description: The company that operates the brand’s retail stores cited a shift in consumer preferences, rising inflation and elevated tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Laura Chung
item.media:credit: Andrew Spear for The New York Times
item.media:description: Eddie Bauer’s retail operator has said it would seek to sell 180 stores across the United States and Canada.

item.title: Watch: A Conversation With Anna Wintour and Her U.S. Vogue Successor, Chloe Malle
item.description: In their first joint interview, Ms. Malle spoke about filling the shoes of Ms. Wintour, who urged people to “get over comparisons.”
item.dc:creator: Jessica Testa, Chevaz Clarke, Daniel Fetherston and Lauren Pruitt

item.title: Pilots and Flight Attendants Criticize American Airlines’ Performance
item.description: The unions representing pilots and flight attendants have in recent days publicly criticized American for falling behind Delta Air Lines and United Airlines.
item.dc:creator: Niraj Chokshi
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: American Airlines had lost substantial ground to Delta Air Lines and United Airlines in recent years.

item.title: Court TV, Known for Live Trial Coverage, Is Getting a New Owner
item.description: E.W. Scripps is selling the channel to the parent company of Law&Crime, which wants Court TV to have a bigger streaming presence.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Hirsch
item.media:credit: James Jackman for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Court TV booth at CrimeCon, an annual true-crime convention.
